title: How to Do Gyotaku    Fish Rubbing

steps.headline: This is a great project to do after a fishing trip with your children.
steps.description: You must use good common sense when working with straight pins; you must have something (a cup works well) to hold them while working; for safety's sake, be certain to account for all of your pins while working, and if you drop one, stop working until it is located and return it to the container. Use good common sense when working with paint and glue. It is a good idea to wear an apron to cover your clothes, or wear old clothes when working with paint! The suggested paint will easily wash off, but the food color in the paint could create permanent stains. You may wish to wear rubber or painters gloves to protect your hands from the dye in the paint!

steps.headline: Before beginning, prepare your work area and gather the needed supplies.
steps.description: For your project, you will need 1. a washable work table (you could cover the floor beneath the work area for safety sake! 2. some artists foam board which is slightly larger than your subject (your fish!) 3. Several sheets of artists rice paper (large size)  4. water and vegetable dye based thick tempura paint 5. a good number of regular straight pins (like those used in sewing), and several inexpensive paint brushes, or foam paint "brushes." You must locate an area (best indoors)  to hang your completed print to dry; a clothes hanger and several hinge type clothes pins, hung over a shower rack or door frame away from high traffic areas, will allow your painting to dry evenly.

steps.headline: Procure your subject!
steps.description: Catch or purchase a good sized fish. Fish with big scales make great rubbings. I prefer to use a fish which I would enjoy eating after my project is completed. I do this to honor the fish; I like to use as much of the fish as possible.

steps.headline: Prepare the fish for painting.
steps.description: Do not cut the fish in half, if you do, you risk removing the pectoral, coital, and dorsal fins of the fish, which add beauty to your art.

steps.headline: Be sure the fish is dead before you beginning.
Wash and dry the fish to get all the slime off.
Using straight pins, position the fish so it looks good to you, being certain to wipe off any blood which may ooze out around the pins, off of the fish.
steps.description: Pin the fish securely onto a large artists foam board, being sure to pin open the fins; pinning the fins open will add beauty to your art.

steps.headline: Paint the fish with the paint, being certain to paint in the direction of the scales, not against the grain of the fish.
steps.description: Make sure to completely cover the fish with paint, eye, fins and all!

steps.headline: Highlight the belly of the fish with a light color (white or yellow) and paint the fins a little bit darker than you paint the body.
steps.description: You want enough paint on the fish to assure a good print, but not so much that all you get is an unrecognizable print, and your goal is to create a print of your fish! Pause and look your fish over before the next step and be sure you like what you see! At this point you can rinse your fish off, and try again! Be certain to remove any gobs of excess paint.

steps.headline: Beginning in the center, press the rice paper down on the fish, and try your best to  press the rest of the paper outward from the center, trying not to get creases in it.
steps.description: Be sure to press the rice paper all over the fish without smearing the paint if possible. Try your best to not press in any folds or creases; small creases will not hurt anything, and may actually add beauty to your print. If you wish, you can use a cloth in between your hands and the rice paper when you do the pressing to ensure even pressure on your subject, or you may use your hands directly on the rice paper for a more rustic appearance.

steps.headline: Remove the paper once you are done pressing the entire fish, and lay your print flat.
Using a small paint brush, paint the eye onto your fish, and enhance the fins if necessary.
Be sure to sign your creation!
steps.description: The print can also be decorated with Asian inspired poetry or you can label your fish with it's species. Artists usually choose to sign in the far right or left hand corners of their work.

steps.headline: Hang your print it to dry in your previously chosen, and hopefully per-setup location.
Using soap and water, wash the foam board you used to pin your fish to when you began the project.
steps.description: Set your foam board aside to dry, being sure to stand it on edge in location where it will not curl or be damaged.

steps.headline: Once your print is dry, attach it along the top edge of the foam board using a glue-stick, or some other water based paint.
steps.description: Attach the top edge only, because this will give your over all creation more contrast.

steps.headline: Go back and thoroughly clean your work area, and put away your supplies.
steps.description: If we clean up after we work, our next project will gain quicker support from others who must share our work area.

steps.headline: Frame your creation!
steps.description: You can make a home made frame, or purchase one that is just right at a hobby store. Be proud of your work, and show it off to others! Please Note: You can do the painting and rubbing (pressing) over and over until you are happy with the results; just be certain to use a new sheet of rice paper each time.

text: This is a great project to do after a fishing trip with your children. You must use good common sense when working with straight pins; you must have something (a cup works well) to hold them while working; for safety's sake, be certain to account for all of your pins while working, and if you drop one, stop working until it is located and return it to the container. Use good common sense when working with paint and glue. It is a good idea to wear an apron to cover your clothes, or wear old clothes when working with paint! The suggested paint will easily wash off, but the food color in the paint could create permanent stains. You may wish to wear rubber or painters gloves to protect your hands from the dye in the paint! Before beginning, prepare your work area and gather the needed supplies. For your project, you will need 1. a washable work table (you could cover the floor beneath the work area for safety sake! 2. some artists foam board which is slightly larger than your subject (your fish!) 3. Several sheets of artists rice paper (large size)  4. water and vegetable dye based thick tempura paint 5. a good number of regular straight pins (like those used in sewing), and several inexpensive paint brushes, or foam paint "brushes." You must locate an area (best indoors)  to hang your completed print to dry; a clothes hanger and several hinge type clothes pins, hung over a shower rack or door frame away from high traffic areas, will allow your painting to dry evenly. Procure your subject! Catch or purchase a good sized fish. Fish with big scales make great rubbings. I prefer to use a fish which I would enjoy eating after my project is completed. I do this to honor the fish; I like to use as much of the fish as possible. Prepare the fish for painting. Do not cut the fish in half, if you do, you risk removing the pectoral, coital, and dorsal fins of the fish, which add beauty to your art. Be sure the fish is dead before you beginning.  Wash and dry the fish to get all the slime off.  Using straight pins, position the fish so it looks good to you, being certain to wipe off any blood which may ooze out around the pins, off of the fish. Pin the fish securely onto a large artists foam board, being sure to pin open the fins; pinning the fins open will add beauty to your art. Paint the fish with the paint, being certain to paint in the direction of the scales, not against the grain of the fish. Make sure to completely cover the fish with paint, eye, fins and all! Highlight the belly of the fish with a light color (white or yellow) and paint the fins a little bit darker than you paint the body. You want enough paint on the fish to assure a good print, but not so much that all you get is an unrecognizable print, and your goal is to create a print of your fish! Pause and look your fish over before the next step and be sure you like what you see! At this point you can rinse your fish off, and try again! Be certain to remove any gobs of excess paint. Beginning in the center, press the rice paper down on the fish, and try your best to  press the rest of the paper outward from the center, trying not to get creases in it. Be sure to press the rice paper all over the fish without smearing the paint if possible. Try your best to not press in any folds or creases; small creases will not hurt anything, and may actually add beauty to your print. If you wish, you can use a cloth in between your hands and the rice paper when you do the pressing to ensure even pressure on your subject, or you may use your hands directly on the rice paper for a more rustic appearance. Remove the paper once you are done pressing the entire fish, and lay your print flat.  Using a small paint brush, paint the eye onto your fish, and enhance the fins if necessary.  Be sure to sign your creation! The print can also be decorated with Asian inspired poetry or you can label your fish with it's species. Artists usually choose to sign in the far right or left hand corners of their work. Hang your print it to dry in your previously chosen, and hopefully per-setup location.  Using soap and water, wash the foam board you used to pin your fish to when you began the project. Set your foam board aside to dry, being sure to stand it on edge in location where it will not curl or be damaged. Once your print is dry, attach it along the top edge of the foam board using a glue-stick, or some other water based paint. Attach the top edge only, because this will give your over all creation more contrast. Go back and thoroughly clean your work area, and put away your supplies. If we clean up after we work, our next project will gain quicker support from others who must share our work area. Frame your creation! You can make a home made frame, or purchase one that is just right at a hobby store. Be proud of your work, and show it off to others! Please Note: You can do the painting and rubbing (pressing) over and over until you are happy with the results; just be certain to use a new sheet of rice paper each time.
sentences: This is a great project to do after a fishing trip with your children.

You must use good common sense when working with straight pins; you must have something (a cup works well) to hold them while working; for safety's sake, be certain to account for all of your pins while working, and if you drop one, stop working until it is located and return it to the container.
Use good common sense when working with paint and glue.
It is a good idea to wear an apron to cover your clothes, or wear old clothes when working with paint!
The suggested paint will easily wash off, but the food color in the paint could create permanent stains.
You may wish to wear rubber or painters gloves to protect your hands from the dye in the paint!
Before beginning, prepare your work area and gather the needed supplies.
For your project, you will need 1. a washable work table (you could cover the floor beneath the work area for safety sake!
2. some artists foam board which is slightly larger than your subject (your fish!)

Several sheets of artists rice paper (large size)  4. water and vegetable dye based thick tempura paint 5. a good number of regular straight pins (like those used in sewing), and several inexpensive paint brushes, or foam paint "brushes."

You must locate an area (best indoors)  to hang your completed print to dry; a clothes hanger and several hinge type clothes pins, hung over a shower rack or door frame away from high traffic areas, will allow your painting to dry evenly.
Procure your subject!
Catch or purchase a good sized fish.
Fish with big scales make great rubbings.
I prefer to use a fish which I would enjoy eating after my project is completed.
I do this to honor the fish; I like to use as much of the fish as possible.
Prepare the fish for painting.
Do not cut the fish in half, if you do, you risk removing the pectoral, coital, and dorsal fins of the fish, which add beauty to your art.
Be sure the fish is dead before you beginning.
Wash and dry the fish to get all the slime off.
Using straight pins, position the fish so it looks good to you, being certain to wipe off any blood which may ooze out around the pins, off of the fish.
Pin the fish securely onto a large artists foam board, being sure to pin open the fins; pinning the fins open will add beauty to your art.
Paint the fish with the paint, being certain to paint in the direction of the scales, not against the grain of the fish.
Make sure to completely cover the fish with paint, eye, fins and all!
Highlight the belly of the fish with a light color (white or yellow) and paint the fins a little bit darker than you paint the body.
You want enough paint on the fish to assure a good print, but not so much that all you get is an unrecognizable print, and your goal is to create a print of your fish!
Pause and look your fish over before the next step and be sure you like what you see!
At this point you can rinse your fish off, and try again!
Be certain to remove any gobs of excess paint.
Beginning in the center, press the rice paper down on the fish, and try your best to  press the rest of the paper outward from the center, trying not to get creases in it.
Be sure to press the rice paper all over the fish without smearing the paint if possible.
Try your best to not press in any folds or creases; small creases will not hurt anything, and may actually add beauty to your print.

If you wish, you can use a cloth in between your hands and the rice paper when you do the pressing to ensure even pressure on your subject, or you may use your hands directly on the rice paper for a more rustic appearance.
Remove the paper once you are done pressing the entire fish, and lay your print flat.
Using a small paint brush, paint the eye onto your fish, and enhance the fins if necessary.
Be sure to sign your creation!
The print can also be decorated with Asian inspired poetry or you can label your fish with it's species.
Artists usually choose to sign in the far right or left hand corners of their work.
Hang your print it to dry in your previously chosen, and hopefully per-setup location.
Using soap and water, wash the foam board you used to pin your fish to when you began the project.
Set your foam board aside to dry, being sure to stand it on edge in location where it will not curl or be damaged.
Once your print is dry, attach it along the top edge of the foam board using a glue-stick, or some other water based paint.
Attach the top edge only, because this will give your over all creation more contrast.
Go back and thoroughly clean your work area, and put away your supplies.
If we clean up after we work, our next project will gain quicker support from others who must share our work area.
Frame your creation!
You can make a home made frame, or purchase one that is just right at a hobby store.
Be proud of your work, and show it off to others!
Please Note: You can do the painting and rubbing (pressing) over and over until you are happy with the results; just be certain to use a new sheet of rice paper each time.
tyn_section: A subject (can be anything but is traditionally a fish or some other form of sea life)
Edible or non-toxic ink (eg., cuttlefish ink, india ink,
(eg., those made from beeswax, plant resins and dyes, or natural minerals such as chalk)
Paper sheets (traditionally, washi or rice paper are used;
be slightly larger than your subject)
A large cloth or washable work table
A small cloth or sponge to remove excess ink/paint
An artist's foam board (should be slightly larger than your fish)
Something to support the subject's pose (such as pins or blocks)
A length of fabric (can be used instead of the paper)
tyn_model: water and vegetable dye based thick tempura paint
